title: Initial Discovery - Nordea Visitor Management
transcriptRaw:
Alex: Thanks for joining today. Can you walk me through your current visitor management process?

Johan: Sure. Right now we use a paper-based sign-in at reception. Visitors fill out a form, get a badge, and that's it. There's no digital trail.

Maria: The biggest issue is compliance. We're a bank — we need to know exactly who was on-site at any given time, and right now we can't produce that report reliably.

Alex: How many visitors do you handle per day across your locations?

Johan: Around 200 across our four main offices. The Helsinki HQ alone sees about 80.

Maria: We've looked at Lenel and Honeywell, but they feel very hardware-heavy. We want something cloud-native that integrates with our existing access control.

Johan: Onboarding is a concern too. Our receptionists aren't technical. If the system is complicated, adoption will fail.

Alex: Understood. What about pre-registration? Do hosts currently notify reception in advance?

Maria: Sometimes, but it's ad hoc — usually an email or a phone call. There's no standardized process.

Johan: We'd love self-service pre-registration where the host sends an invite and the visitor gets a QR code.

Alex: That's definitely something we support. Let me schedule a demo focused on your compliance and pre-registration needs.

insights.summary: Nordea uses paper-based visitor sign-in across 4 offices (~200 visitors/day). Main drivers are compliance reporting and digitization. They want cloud-native, easy onboarding, and self-service pre-registration. Evaluated Lenel and Honeywell but found them too hardware-heavy.

title: Discovery Call - Volvo Factory Access
transcriptRaw:
Alex: Tell me about the current access process for visitors and contractors at your factories.

Anders: It's a mess, honestly. Contractors need to check in at the gate, show ID, get a temporary badge. But there's no system linking their visit to the work order.

Karin: Safety is our number one priority. We had an incident last year where an unauthorized contractor entered a restricted zone. That accelerated this project.

Alex: How many contractor visits do you handle per week?

Anders: Across our three Swedish plants, roughly 500 per week. Torslanda alone is about 250.

Karin: We need integration with our safety training system. Contractors should not get access until they've completed the required safety modules.

Anders: We've been talking to Genetec and HID's competitor Brivo. Genetec is strong on the video side but weak on visitor management.

Alex: Our PIAM platform handles contractor pre-registration, safety training verification, and zone-based access control. Let me show you how that works.

Karin: The onboarding process for new contractors is painful. It takes days to get them badged. We need same-day provisioning.

Anders: And everything needs to work offline at the gate. Internet connectivity at the plants is spotty.

insights.summary: Volvo needs contractor access management across 3 Swedish plants (~500 visits/week). Triggered by unauthorized access incident. Key needs: link visits to work orders, safety training verification before access, same-day contractor provisioning, offline capability at gates.

title: Requirements Workshop - Siemens Campus Security
transcriptRaw:
Alex: What's driving the security upgrade initiative?

Thomas: We're consolidating three campuses into one mega-campus in Munich. 15,000 employees, plus up to 2,000 visitors daily. The current patchwork of systems won't scale.

Anna: We have five different visitor management tools across the campuses. Some are paper, some are outdated digital systems from 2015. Nothing talks to each other.

Thomas: Compliance with ISO 27001 is mandatory. We need a full audit trail of every person on campus.

Alex: That's a significant scale. How do you handle VIP visitors today?

Anna: Poorly. VIPs still wait in line like everyone else. We need a fast-track lane with pre-approved access.

Thomas: We're also evaluating Honeywell's Pro-Watch and Lenel OnGuard. But we've heard their cloud offerings are immature.

Anna: The onboarding complexity worries me. Training 50 reception staff across shifts is not trivial.

Thomas: Budget isn't the primary concern — reliability and compliance are. But we do need a phased rollout plan.

Alex: Absolutely. We typically recommend starting with one building, proving the workflow, then expanding. Let me put together a phased proposal.

title: PKI Discovery - Siemens Device Certificates
transcriptRaw:
Alex: Klaus, can you describe your current certificate management situation?

Klaus: We have around 50,000 IoT devices across our factories that need certificates for mutual TLS. Right now we're managing them manually with OpenSSL scripts and spreadsheets.

Thomas: It's a security risk. Certificates expire without warning, and when they do, production lines stop.

Klaus: We need automated lifecycle management — issuance, renewal, revocation. And it has to scale to 200,000 devices over the next two years.

Alex: What's your current CA infrastructure?

Klaus: We have a Microsoft CA internally, but it doesn't handle IoT scale well. We've looked at Venafi and DigiCert, but Venafi is extremely expensive and DigiCert's IoT offering is still new.

Thomas: Integration with our Azure IoT Hub is critical. Devices register there and need certificates provisioned automatically.

Klaus: Also, we need support for short-lived certificates — some devices need hourly rotation for zero-trust compliance.

Alex: Our PKI-as-a-Service handles all of that. Let me walk you through our Azure IoT Hub integration and the automated rotation policies.

insights.summary: Siemens manages 50K IoT devices needing mTLS certificates, scaling to 200K. Currently manual (OpenSSL + spreadsheets). Certificate expiry causes production outages. Need automated lifecycle management, Azure IoT Hub integration, and short-lived certificate rotation for zero-trust.

title: PKI Requirements - Airbus Infrastructure
transcriptRaw:

title: Technical Deep-Dive - Airbus Multi-Site Architecture
transcriptRaw:
Alex: Marc, let's dig into the technical requirements for multi-site federation.

Marc: Our primary concern is data sovereignty. Each country has different regulations — French data stays in France, German data in Germany. But we need a unified view.

Isabelle: The system needs to handle peak loads during aircraft delivery events. We can have 500 visitors in a single day at Toulouse during a delivery.

Marc: Latency is critical at the gates. Badge validation must happen in under 2 seconds, even during peak.

Alex: Our architecture uses regional pods with a global sync layer. Data stays in-country but profiles are federated.

Marc: What about disaster recovery? If the Toulouse pod goes down, can Hamburg take over?

Alex: Yes, we have active-passive failover between pods with a 15-minute RPO.

Isabelle: We've also re-evaluated Genetec since our last call. Their new cloud offering is competitive, but they admitted multi-site federation is on their 2026 roadmap, not available today.

Marc: Integration with our SAP system for contractor management is a must. Contractor work orders live in SAP.

Alex: We have a certified SAP connector. Let me show you the integration architecture.

insights.summary: Technical deep-dive on multi-site architecture. Key requirements: data sovereignty (country-specific data residency), sub-2-second gate validation at peak (500 visitors/day during deliveries), DR failover between sites, SAP integration for contractor work orders. Genetec re-evaluated but multi-site is on 2026 roadmap.
